titlestmt.title: Moses Erecting the Brazen Serpent : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the Library of Congress

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 8KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 146KB to 1800KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and ArchivesMarch 2010
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of 20 of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. These designs illustrate the Old Testament and are arranged according to the passages illustrated. They are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
The Bible had an enormous influence on Blake’s work as both artist and poet. Among his many and complex responses to that text are water color drawings. The present group of 20 is selected from a sequence of about 80 biblical water colors of similar size Blake painted for Thomas Butts between c. 1800 and 1805. These designs emphasize interactions between the human and the divine. In works such as Ezekiel’s Wheels and David Delivered Out of Many Waters, the interaction is revelatory or redemptive. In other designs, including Pestilence: The Death of the First-Born, the relationship between God and humankind devolves into punishment and destruction.
This group of 20 water colors is the first installment in our publication of a large selection of Blake’s water color drawings illustrating the Bible. In coming months we will publish a group of New Testament illustrations also from the series executed for Butts. Later we will add early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, including Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes of c. 1824.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color over pencil
objinfo.watermark: none visibleThe leaf bearing Blake's water color is glued to a backing mat; this prevents inspection for a watermark.

provenance.name: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
provenance.price: $5,000 for the group of 32 works by Blake (see the note on provenance below)
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1801-03; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold from his collection, Foster and Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 120, titled "The Fiery Serpents" (£1.12s. to the dealer H. G. Bohn); John Clark Strange by 1863; the dealer Bernard Quaritch, offered in his catalogue 350 of 10 Aug. 1883, in item 13,842 with 31 other works by Blake in three volumes (£1,200), in the same group at the same price in Quaritch's advertising flyer of William Blake's Original Drawings of May 1885 and Nov. 1886, and in Quaritch's *General Catalogue of Books* of 1887, item 13,842, in the same group (£1,200); one of the "Nine large Drawings to illustrate the Bible" offered with the same group of three volumes of works by Blake in Quaritch's 1890 Hand-List of a Peerless Collection of Books and Manuscripts Exhibited to the Bibliophiles of America, item 156 ($5,000); the entire group in three volumes sold by Quaritch in 1890 to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

desc.objtitle: Moses Erecting the Brazen Serpent, Object 1 (Butlin 447)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work, lower right, with his monogram; see the textual transcription. A few lines on the backing mat, just below the lower right margin of the water color, might be fragments of an inscription, including the letter "u".

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design illustrates Numbers 22:6-9. Dominating the center of this design is a large pole with a horizontal log at the top, so that the pole resembles a cross. Around the pole is wrapped a large serpent covered in scales. Its crested head faces up. Its mouth is open with one tooth and extended tongue visible. To the left of the pole stands a male figure, presumably Moses, facing away and slightly right. He wears a gown and has curly hair and a beard. His arms are at his side, palms down, and his left leg is bent back and on tiptoe. He seems to be looking up at the serpent on the pole. A large serpent is wrapped around Moses's waist and shoulders. Its crested head lies on the ground to the right of Moses, with its visible eye closed. It may be sleeping or dead. To either side of Moses stands a small child, presumably female, with long hair and a gown. The child to the left of Moses stands, facing to the right. Her head is bowed. The girl to the right of Moses stands, facing left. Her left leg may be extended backward. To the left of the serpent's pole, three nude, male figures hover in the air; each figure has a serpent entwining him. The leftmost figure faces away, with his left leg bent. He has short hair and bends his arms upward to cover his head. The serpent entwined around this figure coils twice around his leg and once around his waist. It faces up, with its mouth open and a crest on its head. Its tongue is extended and it may be breathing fire. The middle figure hovers in mid-air, upside down. His legs are bent and his left arm appears to be raised over his head. His mouth is open. The serpent coiled around this figure has three loops in this tail and wraps around his waist and neck. Its head faces to the right and slightly down. Its head is crested and its mouth is open, displaying two fangs and a tongue. It may also breathe fire. A trail of fire may extend from this serpent's tail or from the man's right leg. This serpent may be looking at the serpent below. The rightmost figure of this group faces right and slightly forward. His right arm is bent over his head and his right leg is bent. He may be partly clothed by a cloth that drapes around his waist and over his right leg. His mouth is open and he has short hair. He may be looking at Moses. The serpent wrapped around this figure has one loop in its tail and wraps around his waist and neck. Its head faces up and its mouth is open, with one tooth and tongue visible. It may also breathe fire at the serpent above, at which it looks. To the right of the serpent's pole, one figure hovers in mid-air. This figure is male and nude, with short, curly hair. He faces away and to the left and is upside down. His right leg is bent backward. The serpent that wraps around this figure has three loops around its tail and coils around his waist and neck. Its head faces to the left and slightly forward, and is crested. Its mouth is open, tongue extended, and may breathe fire as well. To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. The leftmost is a nude male figure who lies, supine, with his head bent back. His mouth is open and he has short, curly hair. He may be partly clothed by a cloth secured around his waist. His arm is at his side and his left leg is bent. The serpent that wraps around this figure coils around his chest and lies with its crested head on the ground to the figure's right. Its one visible eye is closed and it may be sleeping or dead. The second-to-left figure is that of a partly nude male with short, curly hair, standing facing forward and to the left. He turns his head to look away. He is partly clothed by a transparent cloth or pair of breeches around his waist. His arms are raised horizontally, palms vertical, and his right leg is bent forward with his left leg extended backward. To the left of this second-to-left figure is a large serpent whose crested head faces up. Its mouth is open with one fang and an extended forked tongue visible. It may breath fire. The middle figure of this group is a female, facing left and forward, though with her head bent back to look upward. She wears a gown and stands with her left leg bent. She may have long hair. Her mouth as partly open and her right arm is bent upward to rest on and perhaps holds the serpent that coils around her. The serpent that coils around this figure wraps around her waist and neck and holds its head facing down. The second-to-right figure of this group is a female who stands, facing forward and to the right slightly. She looks upward and bends her arms, with her hands held together as if in prayer or supplication. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her mouth is slightly open. The rightmost figure of this group is a gowned female, facing left and slightly away. She is small and thus may be a child. She has long hair and bends her head down to rest on her left hand. Her left arm is bent upward. The earth in the foreground appears to be grassy. The sky backing this scene is slightly cloudy and has hints of fire, perhaps from the serpents or from sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Dominating the center of this design is a large pole with a horizontal log at the top, so that the pole resembles a cross. A serpent coils around the pole.
Around the pole is wrapped a large serpent covered in scales. Its crested head faces up. Its mouth is open with one tooth and extended tongue visible.

To the left of the pole stands a male figure, presumably Moses, facing away and slightly right. He wears a gown and has curly hair and a beard. His arms are at his side, palms down, and his left leg is bent back and on tiptoe. A large serpent is wrapped around his waist and shoulders. He seems to be looking up at the serpent on the pole.
A large serpent is wrapped around Moses's waist and shoulders. Its crested head lies on the ground to Moses's right, with its one visible eye closed. It may be sleeping or dead.
To either side of Moses stands a small child, presumably female, with long hair and a gown. The child to the left of Moses stands, facing away to the right. Her head is bowed.
To either side of Moses stands a small child, presumably female, with long hair and a gown. The girl to the right of Moses stands, facing left. Her left leg may be extended backward.

To the left of the serpent's pole, three nude, male figures hover in the air; each figure has a serpent entwining him. The leftmost figure faces away, with his left leg bent. He has short hair and bends his arms upward to cover his head. He may wear short breaches.

To the left of the serpent's pole, three nude, male figures hover in the air; each figure has a serpent entwining him. The serpent entwined around the leftmost figure of this group coils twice around his leg and once around his waist. It faces up, with its mouth open and a crest on its head. Its tongue is extended and it may be breathing fire.

To the left of the serpent's pole, three nude, male figures hover in the air; each figure has a serpent entwining him. The uppermost figure hovers in mid-air, upside down. He faces forward and to the left. His legs are bent and his left arm appears to be raised over his head. His mouth is open; he may be screaming or howling in pain.

To the left of the serpent's pole, three nude, male figures hover in the air; each figure has a serpent entwining him. The serpent coiled around the middle figure of this group has three loops in this tail and wraps around his waist and neck. Its head faces to the right and slightly down. Its head is crested and its mouth is open, displaying two fangs and a forked tongue. It may also breathe fire. A trail of fire may extend from this serpent's tail or from the man's right leg. The serpent may be looking at the serpent to its right.

To the left of the serpent's pole, three nude, male figures hover in the air; each figure has a serpent entwining him. The rightmost figure of this group faces right and slightly forward. His right arm is bent over his head and his right leg is bent. He may be partly clothed by a cloth that drapes around his waist and over his right leg. His mouth is open and he has short hair. He may be screaming or howling in pain. He may be looking at Moses.

To the left of the serpent's pole, three nude, male figures hover in the air; each figure has a serpent entwining him. The serpent wrapped around the rightmost figure of this group has one loop in its tail and wraps around his waist and neck. Its head faces up and its mouth is open, with one tooth and perhaps multiple tongues visible. It may also breathe fire at the serpent to its left, at which it looks.

To the right of the serpent's pole, one figure hovers in mid-air. This figure is male and nude, with short, curly hair. A serpent is coiled around him. He faces away and to the left and is upside down. His right leg is bent backward.

To the right of the serpent's pole, one figure hovers in mid-air. The serpent that wraps around this figure has three loops around its tail and coils around his waist and neck. Its head faces to the left and slightly forward, and is crested. Its mouth is open with extended tongue; it may breathe fire as well.

To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. The leftmost is a nude male figure who lies, supine, with his head bent back. His mouth is open and he has short, curly hair. He may be partly clothed by a cloth secured around his waist. His left arm is at his side and his left leg is bent. A serpent coils around him. He is probably in pain.

To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. The serpent that wraps around the leftmost figure of this group coils around his chest and lies with its crested head on the ground to the figure's right. Its one visible eye is closed and it may be sleeping or dead.

To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. The second-to-left figure is that of a partly nude male with short, curly hair, standing facing forward and to the left. He turns his head to look away. He is partly clothed by a cloth or pair of breeches around his waist. His arms are raised horizontally, palms vertical, and his right leg is bent forward with his left leg extended backward. He may be walking or striding forward.

To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. To the left of the second-to-left human figure of this group is a large serpent whose crested head faces up. Its mouth is open with one fang and an extended forked tongue visible. It may breath fire.

To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. The middle figure of this group is a female, facing left and forward, though with her head bent back to look upward. She wears a gown and stands with her left leg bent. She may have long hair. Her mouth as partly open and her right arm is bent upward to rest on and perhaps hold the serpent that coils around her.
To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. The serpent that coils around the middle figure of this group wraps around her waist and neck and holds its head facing down.

To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. The second-to-right figure of this group is a female who stands, facing forward and to the right slightly. She looks upward and bends her arms, with her hands held together as if in prayer or supplication. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her mouth is slightly open.

To the right of the serpent's pole are five human figures on the ground. The rightmost figure of this group is a gowned female, facing left and slightly away. She is small and so may be a child. She has long hair and bends her head down to rest on her left hand. Her left arm is bent upward, with her left hand on her face.
The earth in the foreground appears to be grassy.
The sky backing this scene is slightly cloudy and has hints of fire, perhaps from the serpents or from sunrise or sunset.
